feed.title: Combined summary - Payment Protocol Proposal: Invoices/Payments/Receipts

entry.title: Combined summary - Payment Protocol Proposal: Invoices/Payments/Receipts
entry.summary: The Bitcoin development community in 2012 was actively discussing various proposals related to invoicing, payment protocols, and identity verification. One proposal involved switching from JSON to binary format for more efficient and secure data transfer. Another proposal involved a new merchant-pays-fee feature that would enable merchants to cover the cost of transaction processing fees in various ways. The Bitcoin Payment Protocol, allowing for a more streamlined and secure payment process through the use of X.509 certificates as the identity system for merchants and multi-signature-capable Bitcoin clients to authorize payments, is also being discussed.Other topics of discussion include using protocol buffer-based formats for signed, authenticated "invoices" and "receipts," support for DNSSEC/DANE, incorporating a unique address per transaction or per customer for better privacy protection, and using signed invoices as virus protection. The importance of security and trust in Bitcoin transactions is emphasized throughout the conversations.There are debates around text versus binary formats, the role of root CAs, how to handle refund addresses and identifying end-users, and whether the focus should be on improving the core of Bitcoin rather than adding new features. Additionally, the discussions include proposals for establishing a top-level IANA registry group and creating a "mediation" system for resolving disputes in payment requests.There are ongoing discussions about various proposals related to invoicing, payment protocols, and identity verification in the Bitcoin-development mailing list. Solutions proposed include broadcasting the transaction or invalidating it by broadcasting a pay-to-self transaction that spends one or more of the same outputs. There were discussions about having the merchant broadcast the transaction during in-person payments using Bluetooth/NFC on a phone and the complexity and edge cases that come with it.Lastly, there are discussions on the implementation of a "pass around" method for Bitcoin transactions and the need for both lower-level and higher-level access to Bitcoin transaction functionality. The email exchange highlights the importance of considering security and privacy implications when making technological decisions. The main topics covered include proposals for a payment protocol utilizing X.509 certificates as the identity system for merchants, concerns about user security and anonymity, and issues related to using textual versus binary formats for data structures. Discussions also touch on the importance of consistency for sellers, the use of SSL certificates/CAs for verifying public keys, and updates to the Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) specification. Additionally, proposed features such as refund address provision, proof-of-payment, and payment requests tied to authenticated identities are discussed. Other topics include the possibility of using alternative identification systems like GPG and hash-based systems, the need for secure messaging between wallets, and concerns about the centralized nature of Bitcoin. Overall, the discussions emphasize the need for a better system to ensure user security while balancing practical considerations like efficiency and ease of use.
